title: Have there been back-up band members that have become famous in their own right, beyond what the front man attained? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’m not sure if this counts, but before becoming huge rock stars in their own right, Jimmy Page and John Paul Jones were session musicians who backed up numerous acts in the recording studio. So was Glen Campbell. So was Leon Russell. Barry Manilow used to play piano for Bette Midler in gay bathhouses, before becoming a huge musical star himself. Mick Jones was the guitarist for Johnny Halliday (“The French Elvis”) for many years, before starting the hugely successful band Foreigner. In the early Sixties, Jimi Hendrix was backup guitarist for many soul and blues stars, including Chuck Berry and Ike/Tina Turner. Keith Emerson and the Nice started out as the backup band for female soul singer PP Arnold. Neal Schon was a backup guitarist for Santana before forming Journey. Waylon Jennings was a guitarist and backup singer for Buddy Holly. Waylon, it could be argued, had a better career than Buddy. Sheryl Crow was a backup singer for many artists (including Don Henley) before becoming a star herself.

“Have there been back-up band members that have become famous in their own right, beyond what the front man attained?” Rockabilly singer Ronnie Hawkins put together a backup group he called The Hawks between the years 1958 and 1963. It was a slow process, hiring a bass player here and a drummer there. The group left him in 1964 and put out a few singles as Levon and the Hawks, and as The Canadian Squires. Bob Dylan heard them, and hired them for his ’65 and ’66 tours, and when they were back in the States helped them to settle in Saugerties New York. They rehearsed with Dylan and he ultimately released The Basement Tapes, the basis of their first album, Music From Big Pink. Since they were known informally by other musicians in the area as “The Band,” they decided to stay with the name and the rest, as they say, is history. The Band - Wikipedia

Fun Boy Three was a short lived New Wave Pop group formed by members of The Specials, Terry Hall, Neville Staple and Lynval Golding. In 1981 they released a cover of 'Tain't What You Do (It's the Way That You Do It. Reached the UK Top Ten. Song’s been stuck in my head since then.  Recognise the backing singers? It’s Bananarama. Unquestionably they became more famous than Fun Boy Three. They weren’t really backing singers though, as they were a band in and of themselves before they were brought in for the single. Nope, Shirley Manson of Garbage is possibly a better example as she certainly was a backing singer for Goodbye Mr Mackenzie before joining Garbage. Curtis Knight and the Squires had a guitarist by the name of Jimi Hendrix (and later one by the name of Fast Eddie Clark who would join Motorhead) One more. P.J. Proby recorded an album in 1969 for which he used a newly formed group. Who would later totally eclipse Proby in terms of fame and success. Unlike The Band. Because they were Led Zeppelin. Fun Boy Three - Wikipedia 'Tain't What You Do (It's the Way That You Do It) - Wikipedia Bananarama - Wikipedia Shirley Manson - Wikipedia Goodbye Mr Mackenzie - Wikipedia Curtis Knight - Wikipedia Jimi Hendrix - Wikipedia Eddie Clarke (musician) - Wikipedia Motörhead - Wikipedia P. J. Proby - Wikipedia Three Week Hero - Wikipedia Led Zeppelin - Wikipedia

The first one that comes to my mind would be Jimi Hendrix. He started up backing up Little Richard and the Isley Brothers. I think he probably surpassed the popularity of both those bands on his own. Staying with the guitar theme, another would be Steve Via. He started as a backup musician for Frank Zappa. Debatable if he's become as or more popular than Frank, but he did expand the fan base.

Phil Collins was the drummer for Genesis when Peter Gabriel was the front man. When Gabriel left the band to pursue a solo career Phil Collins auditioned for the lead vocalist to replace him. While Gabriel has a relatively successful solo career, Genesis grew stronger with Collins more mainstream rock and power ballads. Collins then left Genesis for a solo career and achieved further success. So Gabriel’s drummer beat him like a drum.

Phil Collins was originally just the drummer for Genesis, when Peter Gabriel left the band to go solo Phil became the front man and of course went on to have a very successful solo career as well. I don't like his music but you can't argue that he was more successful commercially than Peter Gabriel ever was.

In the late 1960s there was a pop band called Simon Dupree and the Big Sound. Their keyboard player had an accident. So the first backup they used was a young undergradute called Dudley Moore. For the tour they hired Reg Dwight. The band morphed into the prog band Gentle Giant - who had cult success but did not really bother the charts.

Two examples I can think of are: a) Glenn Frey and Don Henley, who backed Linda Ronstadt and then became the core of the Eagles, and b) Phil Collins, who first made a name for himself as Genesis’ drummer behind Peter Gabriel.
The Band, once Bob Dylan’s back up band, although they had been a good band before he recruited them. They became better well known after backing Dylan.

Arguably Fat Boy Slim…he was the bass player in The Housemartins. Phil Collins was just the drummer in Genesis when Peter Gabriel was the singer. Bobby Gillespie (Primal Scream) used to be the drummer in the Jesus and Mary Chain
